title: How to Add Seaweed to Your Diet

steps.headline: Make a seaweed salad.
steps.description: Seaweed salad is popular in Japan, and it’s a cinch to make. Just put 1 ounce (28 g) of dry mixed seaweed in a bowl. Fill the bowl with cold water. Let the seaweed rehydrate for 5 minutes if you like crunchy seaweed. If you like softer seaweed, allow it to rehydrate for 10 minutes. In a small mixing bowl, combine 1 tablespoon of rice vinegar, 1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil, 1 tablespoon soy sauce, 1 tablespoon sugar, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon ginger juice. Add an additional teaspoon of rice vinegar for good measure. Drain the seaweed. Wring out any excess water by squeezing it gently by hand. Wipe the bowl down and put the seaweed back in the bowl. Pour the ginger/soy sauce dressing over it. Mix the dressing and seaweed so that the seaweed is thoroughly coated. Top with 1 tablespoon toasted sesame seeds and 1 diced scallion. Seaweed salad is great on its own or as a topping for burgers.

steps.headline: Make sunomono.
steps.description: Sunomono is a twist on the regular seaweed salad. To get started, combine 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) rice vinegar, 1/8 teaspoon soy sauce, 2 tablespoons soy sauce, and 1.5 teaspoons lemon juice in a small bowl. Set aside. Put 2.5 tablespoons dried wakame seaweed in a bowl with 12 fluid ounces (350 mL) of water. Set aside for about 10 minutes and allow the seaweed to rehydrate. Slice 2 or 3 Japanese or Persian cucumbers into thin slices. In a third bowl, mix the cucumber slices with a generous amount of salt. Allow the salt to remove moisture from the cucumber for about 10 minutes. Rinse the cucumber slices off in a colander. Gently squeeze any water that may have been reabsorbed by placing the slices between a few sheets of paper towel and pressing the water out. Mix the cucumber and wakame, then pour a tablespoon or 2 of the dressing over each serving.

steps.headline: Make a seaweed dressing.
steps.description: Instead of making seaweed the star of your salad, give it a supporting role. Heat 2 toasted nori sheets up in the oven on your oven’s lowest setting. Check the sheets frequently. When they turn slightly brown and crispy, remove them. Break them into smaller pieces and grind them with a mortar and pestle. Pour the nori dust in a blender and combine with 1 tablespoon orange zest, ½ tablespoon salt, 2 tablespoons sesame oil, and 6 fluid ounces (180 mL) of rice wine vinegar. Pour it in an empty dressing bottle or squirt bottle. Refrigerate and shake well before use. Seaweed dressing is great over roasted veggies or salads, and also works well as a marinade for fish.

steps.headline: Try a seaweed soup.
steps.description: Seaweed soup is a popular dish in Korea, where it is known as miyeok-guk. To make some tasty seaweed soup for yourself, soak 1 ounce (28 g) of dried brown seaweed in warm water for about 10 minutes. Drain the water and gently squeeze out excess water by hand. Cut the seaweed into 2-inch (4-centimeter) strips. Coat a saucepan with 2 teaspoons of sesame oil, then add 0.25 pounds (110 g) minced beef top sirloin, ½ tablespoon soy sauce, a pinch of salt. Cook over medium heat for 1 minute. Stir in the rehydrated seaweed and 1 tablespoon soy sauce. Cook for 1 minute. Stir frequently. Pour 16 fluid ounces (470 mL) of water into the saucepan. Bring the pan to a boil. Add 1 teaspoon minced garlic and 32 fluid ounces (950 mL) water. Return the pan to a boil, then cover. Reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes. Remove from heat and allow to cool slightly before eating. Add salt to taste.

steps.headline: Cook your rice.
steps.description: Sushi (or its Korean cousin, gimbap) is the most popular and well-known food containing seaweed. To get started making sushi, cook 16 ounces (450 g) of short-grain white rice.

steps.headline: Marinate the tofu.
steps.description: While the rice is cooking, combine 2 teaspoons honey, 1 teaspoon minced garlic, and 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) soy sauce in a wide pan. Chop 3 ounces (85 g) of firm tofu into 0.5 inches (1.3 cm)  wide strips. Marinate the strips in the soy sauce/garlic mix.

steps.headline: Prepare your veggies.
steps.description: While the rice is cooking and the tofu is marinating, julienne 1 small carrot, half of a cucumber, and half of an avocado. Once the rice has cooked for about 20 minutes, mix 2 tablespoons rice vinegar into it.

steps.headline: Assemble the sushi.
steps.description: Place a sheet of nori on a cutting board or large flat surface in front of you. Spread a thin layer of rice evenly across the surface of the nori. Leave a gap at the top and bottom edge of the nori sheet. Lay the tofu strips on the rice in a top-to-bottom orientation. But don’t use it all at once. Put only enough to stretch from the top edge of the nori sheet to the bottom in a thin line. Do the same with the carrot strips, avocado, and cucumber.

steps.headline: Roll the sushi.
steps.description: Turn the nori sheet so that the fillings are now oriented in a side-to-side position. From the end closest to you, gently roll the sushi away from you to form as tight a cylinder as possible. If you have a bamboo sushi-rolling mat, you can use it to make a prettier and more symmetrical sushi roll. You’ll need to remove and readjust the position of the mat temporarily to allow you to continue rolling, otherwise you’ll end up rolling the mat right into the roll. Cut the sushi roll into slices 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) wide using a sharp knife. This recipe should provide enough tofu, rice, and veggies to make 4 or 5 sushi rolls. There are many opportunities for experimenting with sushi. You can add fish or crab meat, cream cheese, radish, beets, cucumber, and many other fillings.

steps.headline: Start your veggie jim.
steps.description: A veggie jim is like a jerky stick, but without the meat. They make a great snack. To get started, blend 12 ounces (340 g) of raw sunflower seeds until they resemble a fine dust. Scoop the blended seeds out and into a bowl.

steps.headline: Make the filling.
steps.description: Wipe the food processor out and add 8 ounces (230 g) raw pumpkin seeds, 4 minced garlic cloves, 2 red bell peppers, 8 fluid ounces (240 mL) of water, 6 tablespoons of lemon juice, 1 teaspoon salt, 1 tablespoon raw grated beet, 2 teaspoons onion powder, and a generous pinch of cayenne pepper (add more if you like your veggie jim spicy). Blend on high until smooth. Add the sunflower seed paste back to the mix and blend again. Your mix should become a mushy paste. You may need to add slightly more water (1 spoonful at a time) in order to get the mixture to achieve the proper consistency. Fill a resealable plastic bag with the mixture. Snip 1 corner off so that you can squeeze the paste from the bag as you would through a piping bag.

steps.headline: Prepare the nori.
steps.description: Lay a strip of nori, shiny side down, on some parchment paper. The strip should be about 2 inches (5.1 cm) wide and 6 inches (15 cm) long. Use a spray bottle to spray the nori with a light mist of water.

steps.headline: Fill the nori with paste.
steps.description: Push the paste out of the bag and lengthwise down the center of the nori. Guide the tip extruding the paste from the top to the bottom of the sheet, squeezing continuously so as to allow an even strip of paste to exit the bag. The paste strip should be no wider than about 0.25 to 0.5 in (0.64 to 1.27 cm).

steps.headline: Finish the veggie jim.
steps.description: Roll the sides of the nori strip over the paste into a tight tube. You can roll the right side over to the left or the left side over to the right. Do not squeeze the tubes as your roll them or the contents will be ejected from either end. If the tubes are not sealing properly when rolled, spray the edges lightly with your spray bottle again. Set the tubes in your dehydrator overnight. Check them in the morning. Take a bite. They are ready when dried out. You can store the veggie jims in an airtight container.

methods.name: Trying Other Seaweed Recipes and Sources

steps.headline: Try a terimayo hot dog.
steps.description: The terimayo hot dog is a Japanese twist on the humble hot dog. To get started, just grill a hot dog in the way you typically prefer to. The terimayo hot dog can be made from lightly or heavily grilled hot dogs. Put the hot dog in a whole wheat bun and drizzle a tablespoon of mayo and a teaspoon of teriyaki sauce over it. Crumble a nori sheet over the hot dog by pulling off small flakes 1 at a time. Coat the mayo and sauce-covered dog in nori flakes. You might not want to use the whole sheet – or maybe you’ll want to use 2!

steps.headline: Make a seaweed chip.
steps.description: Seaweed chips are a crispy snack you can enjoy any time of day. To get started, mix 1/2 teaspoon brown sugar, 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger, 1/4 teaspoon paprika, 1/4 teaspoon oriental mustard, and 1/4 teaspoon salt in a small bowl. Brush sesame oil in an even layer onto 1 side of a roasted seaweed sheet. Sprinkle the spice mixture in a generous layer across the oiled surface of the seaweed. Heat a nonstick pan over medium heat. Toast the sheets of seaweed for 10 to 15 seconds per side. Pull the seaweed sheets apart along their separation lines to make discrete chips. Alternately, use scissors to cut the seaweed into triangular chips. The amount of spice mixture available will allow you to make 5 or six sheets of seaweed chips.

steps.headline: Make a seaweed mayo.
steps.description: All you have to do is grind 3 toasted nori sheets in a spice mill or blender. Then, mix the nori powder into 1 cup of mayo and 2 teaspoons of lime juice. Enjoy your tasty nori mayo. Seaweed mayo is a great dip for crackers, carrot chips, or cucumber slices. You can also spread it on sandwiches and wraps.

steps.headline: Try a green seaweed smoothie.
steps.description: Seaweed can be added to almost any smoothie in the form of kelp powder and dulse flakes. You can add half a teaspoon or more, to taste. Don’t add too much, though, as seaweed tends to have a relatively salty flavor. For instance, mix 1 banana, 1 mango, 4 strawberries, 1 packed cup of kale, 8 fluid ounces (240 mL) of milk, 3 ice cubes, and 1 teaspoon of dulse flakes in your blender. Blend on high until everything is well mixed. Add more water in 1-teaspoon increments if you find it is too thick.

steps.headline: Drink seaweed tea.
steps.description: Seaweed tea is easy to make. Boil 4 fluid ounces (120 mL) of water. Place ½ teaspoon of powdered kombu in a mug. Pour the boiling water over the kombu and mix it gently for a few seconds. Allow tea to stand about 5 minutes. Drink and enjoy.

steps.headline: Try a seaweed supplement.
steps.description: Seaweed supplements have all the benefits that direct seaweed consumption has, but allow you to obtain them without actually adding seaweed foods to your diet. There are many brands of seaweed supplements available. Ask your doctor for a recommendation of a reputable seaweed supplement at a concentration that is compatible with your age, sex, and overall health. Claims that iodine in seaweed can protect against radioactive iodine should not be taken seriously. Keep in mind that supplements are not regulated by the FDA, so it is important to look for a product that has received third party certification, such as a product that has a USP seal.
